description: PFC command documentation index for quick lookup and LLM-assisted command discovery

ball.description: Commands for creating, modifying, and managing ball objects in PFC discrete element simulations
notes: Ball commands typically operate on ranges (groups, spatial regions, or all balls)
Use Python SDK for fine-grained control and complex logic
Use commands for batch operations and initial model setup
Ball generation with packing patterns requires commands (not available in Python SDK)

commands.name: accumulate-stress
commands.short_description: Specify that stresses are accumulated and stored during cycling
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('ball accumulate-stress <bool>')

commands.name: attribute
commands.short_description: Set the value of ball attributes
commands.python_alternative: Use Ball.set_*() methods (e.g., Ball.set_density(), Ball.set_vel(), Ball.set_pos()) - requires iteration over ball range

commands.name: clump
commands.short_description: Create a single clump from the balls within range or add a ball to an existing clump
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('ball clump ...') - Python SDK cannot convert balls to clump pebbles

commands.name: create
commands.short_description: Create a single ball with the specified attributes
commands.python_alternative: itasca.ball.create(radius, centroid, id=None) - creates single ball with specified parameters

commands.name: delete
commands.short_description: Delete balls
commands.python_alternative: Ball.delete() method - requires iteration: for b in itasca.ball.list(): b.delete()

commands.name: distribute
commands.short_description: Distribute balls with overlaps until a target porosity is achieved
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('ball distribute ...') - no Python SDK equivalent for porosity-based distribution with overlaps

commands.name: export
commands.short_description: Export balls to geometry sets for post-processing or STL export
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('ball export geometry ...') - no Python SDK equivalent for geometry export

commands.name: extra
commands.short_description: Set ball extra variables
commands.python_alternative: Ball.set_extra(slot, value) - requires iteration: for b in itasca.ball.list(): b.set_extra(i, value)

commands.name: fix
commands.short_description: Fix the specified ball velocities
commands.python_alternative: Ball.set_fix(component, True) where component: 0=X, 1=Y, 2=Z, 3=RX, 4=RY, 5=RZ - requires iteration

commands.name: free
commands.short_description: Free the specified ball velocities
commands.python_alternative: Ball.set_fix(component, False) where component: 0=X, 1=Y, 2=Z, 3=RX, 4=RY, 5=RZ - requires iteration

commands.name: generate
commands.short_description: Generate non-overlapping balls
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('ball generate ...') - Python SDK only has itasca.ball.create() for single ball creation

commands.name: group
commands.short_description: Specify ball group names
commands.python_alternative: Ball.set_group(group_name, slot=None) - requires iteration: for b in itasca.ball.list(): b.set_group('name')

commands.name: history
commands.short_description: Add a history of a ball value
commands.syntax: ball history name <name> <keyword> id <i> or position <v>
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('ball history ...') or manually record values using itasca.set_callback() with Ball getter methods

commands.name: initialize
commands.short_description: Modify ball attributes
commands.python_alternative: Same as ball attribute: use Ball.set_*() methods - requires iteration

commands.name: list
commands.short_description: List ball information
commands.python_alternative: Ball getter methods: Ball.pos(), Ball.vel(), Ball.radius(), Ball.density(), etc. - requires iteration: for b in itasca.ball.list(): print(b.pos())

commands.name: property
commands.short_description: Assign ball surface properties used in contact models
commands.python_alternative: Ball.set_prop(property_name, value) - requires iteration: for b in itasca.ball.list(): b.set_prop('kn', 1e8)

commands.name: results
commands.short_description: Configure ball results logic for efficient post-processing
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('ball results ...') - Python SDK does not provide results configuration

commands.name: tolerance
commands.short_description: Set contact detection tolerances
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('ball tolerance ...') - Python SDK does not provide tolerance settings

commands.name: trace
commands.short_description: Add a ball particle trace to record and visualize ball motion path
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('ball trace ...') - Python SDK does not provide trace creation. Use trace commands for manipulation.

commands.name: tractions
commands.short_description: Compute contact tractions consistent with prescribed stress state using Voronoi tessellation
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('ball tractions ...') - Python SDK does not provide Voronoi-based traction computation

clump.description: Clump object creation, modification, and template management commands. Clumps are rigid aggregates of overlapping or touching balls (pebbles) that behave as single rigid bodies.
notes: Clumps are rigid bodies composed of pebbles (component balls)
Clump templates enable efficient replication of complex shapes
clump generate creates non-overlapping clumps; clump distribute allows overlaps for target porosity
Most clump operations (template, generate, distribute) not available in Python SDK

commands.name: accumulate-stress
commands.short_description: Specify that stresses are accumulated and stored during cycling
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump accumulate-stress <bool>')

commands.name: attribute
commands.short_description: Set the value of clump attributes
commands.python_alternative: Use Clump.set_*() methods (e.g., Clump.set_density(), Clump.set_vel(), Clump.set_pos()) - requires iteration over clump range

commands.name: break
commands.short_description: Break clumps into pebbles
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump break ...') - Python SDK cannot directly break clumps into pebbles

commands.name: create
commands.short_description: Create a single clump with the specified attributes
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump create ...') - Python SDK cannot directly create clumps with pebbles

commands.name: delete
commands.short_description: Delete clumps and/or pebbles
commands.python_alternative: Use Clump.delete() method - requires iteration over clump range to delete multiple clumps

commands.name: distribute
commands.short_description: Distribute clumps with overlaps
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump distribute ...') - Python SDK cannot directly distribute clumps with templating system

commands.name: export
commands.short_description: Export clumps to geometry sets for post-processing or STL export
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump export geometry ...') - no Python SDK equivalent for geometry export

commands.name: extra
commands.short_description: Set clump or pebble extra variables
commands.python_alternative: Clump.set_extra(slot, value) for clumps - requires iteration: for c in itasca.clump.list(): c.set_extra(i, value). For pebbles: use Ball.set_extra() on pebble balls

commands.name: fix
commands.short_description: Fix the specified clump velocities
commands.python_alternative: Clump.set_fix(component, True) where component: 0=X, 1=Y, 2=Z, 3=RX, 4=RY, 5=RZ - requires iteration: for c in itasca.clump.list(): c.set_fix(component, True)

commands.name: free
commands.short_description: Free the specified clump velocities
commands.python_alternative: Clump.set_fix(component, False) where component: 0=X, 1=Y, 2=Z, 3=RX, 4=RY, 5=RZ - requires iteration: for c in itasca.clump.list(): c.set_fix(component, False)

commands.name: generate
commands.short_description: Generate non-overlapping clumps
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump generate ...') - Python SDK cannot directly generate clumps with templating system

commands.name: group
commands.short_description: Specify clump or pebble group names
commands.python_alternative: Clump.set_group(group_name, slot=None) for clumps - requires iteration: for c in itasca.clump.list(): c.set_group('name'). For pebbles: use Ball.set_group() on pebble balls

commands.name: history
commands.short_description: Add a history of a clump value
commands.syntax: clump history name <name> <keyword> id <i> or position <v>
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump history ...') or manually record values using itasca.set_callback() with Clump getter methods

commands.name: initialize
commands.short_description: Modify clump attributes
commands.python_alternative: Same as clump attribute: use Clump.set_*() methods (e.g., Clump.set_density(), Clump.set_vel(), Clump.set_pos()) - requires iteration over clump range

commands.name: list
commands.short_description: List clump information
commands.python_alternative: Clump getter methods: Clump.pos(), Clump.vel(), Clump.density(), Clump.volume(), etc. - requires iteration: for c in itasca.clump.list(): print(c.pos())

commands.name: order
commands.short_description: Set the rotational EOM (Equations of Motion) order for clumps (3D ONLY)
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump order <i>') - no direct Python SDK method to set rotational EOM order

commands.name: property
commands.short_description: Assign clump or pebble surface properties used in contact models
commands.python_alternative: For pebbles: iterate over clumps, then over pebbles (balls) in each clump, and use Ball.set_prop(property_name, value). Example: for c in itasca.clump.list(): for p in c.pebbles(): p.set_prop('kn', 1e8)

commands.name: replicate
commands.short_description: Create a single clump from a template
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump replicate ...') - Python SDK cannot directly replicate clumps from templates

commands.name: results
commands.short_description: Configure clump results logic for efficient post-processing
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump results ...') - Python SDK does not provide results configuration

commands.name: rotate
commands.short_description: Rotate clumps using right-hand rule
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump rotate ...') - Python SDK does not provide direct clump rotation method

commands.name: scale
commands.short_description: Scale clumps
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump scale ...') - Python SDK does not provide direct clump scaling method

commands.name: template
commands.short_description: Operate on a single clump template
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump template ...') - Python SDK does not provide direct clump template management

commands.name: tolerance
commands.short_description: Set contact detection tolerances
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump tolerance ...') - Python SDK does not provide direct tolerance control

commands.name: trace
commands.short_description: Add a clump or pebble particle trace
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump trace ...') - Python SDK does not provide direct particle trace creation

contact.description: Commands for configuring contact models and managing contact properties between objects
notes: Contact models define mechanical behavior at contact points
Common contact models: linear, linearpbond, linearcbond, hertz
Contact properties are model-specific (e.g., 'kn' for normal stiffness)
Use 'contact model' commands to assign and configure models

commands.name: activate
commands.short_description: Change the contact activate flag for existing contacts

commands.name: apply-group
commands.short_description: Apply contact group names to contacting pieces or bodies
commands.python_alternative:
itasca.command('contact apply-group ...') - Python SDK does not provide direct apply-group functionality. Manual implementation requires:
1. Iterate through contacts
2. Get contact group name: contact.group(slot)
3. Get contact ends: contact.end1(), contact.end2()
4. Apply group to pieces/bodies: piece.set_group() or body.set_group()

Example:
for c in it.contact.list():
    group_name = c.group('Default')
    if group_name:
        c.end1().set_group(group_name, 'Default')
        c.end2().set_group(group_name, 'Default')

commands.name: cmat add
commands.short_description: Adds a new entry to the CMAT (Contact Model Assignment Table)
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('contact cmat add ...') - Python SDK does not provide direct CMAT API, must use command interface

commands.name: cmat apply
commands.short_description: Apply the CMAT to existing contacts
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('contact cmat apply ...') - Python SDK does not provide direct CMAT API, must use command interface

commands.name: cmat default
commands.short_description: Set the default slot(s) of the CMAT
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('contact cmat default ...') - Python SDK does not provide direct CMAT API, must use command interface

commands.name: cmat list
commands.short_description: Lists the CMAT (Contact Model Assignment Table)
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('contact cmat list') - Python SDK does not provide direct CMAT API, must use command interface. Output goes to console, cannot be captured directly in Python.

commands.name: cmat modify
commands.short_description: Modify an existing entry in the CMAT (Contact Model Assignment Table)
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('contact cmat modify ...') - Python SDK does not provide direct CMAT API, must use command interface

commands.name: cmat proximity
commands.short_description: Set the contact detection distance for the CMAT (Contact Model Assignment Table)
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('contact cmat proximity <value>') - Python SDK does not provide direct CMAT proximity API, must use command interface

commands.name: cmat remove
commands.short_description: Remove an entry from the CMAT (Contact Model Assignment Table)
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('contact cmat remove <i>') - Python SDK does not provide direct CMAT API, must use command interface

commands.name: delete
commands.short_description: Delete contacts in the specified range
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('contact delete range ...') - Python SDK does not provide direct contact deletion API. Individual Contact objects become invalid when deleted, but there's no contact.delete() method. Use command interface for contact deletion.

commands.name: detection
commands.short_description: Control whether contacts are automatically detected during simulation
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('contact detection <on/off>') - Python SDK does not provide direct contact detection control API. Must use command interface.

commands.name: fix
commands.short_description: Fix contacts in the specified range
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('contact fix <bval> range ...') - Python SDK does not provide direct contact fix functionality. No contact.fix() method exists in the SDK.

commands.name: group
commands.short_description: Assign group names to contacts for organization and range-based selection

commands.name: inhibit
commands.short_description: Inhibit (disable) contacts in the specified range

commands.name: method
commands.short_description: Execute contact model methods on existing contacts

commands.name: model
commands.short_description: Assign contact models to existing contacts

commands.name: persist
commands.short_description: Set the contact persistence flag for contacts in the specified range

commands.name: property
commands.short_description: Assign contact properties to existing contacts

fragment.description: Fragment tracking and analysis commands for connected component detection in contact networks. Fragments identify groups of connected bodies based on contact connectivity.
typical_workflow: 2. Compute or activate: fragment compute OR fragment activate cycles 100
3. Query fragment IDs: ball.fragment() or clump.fragment() in Python
notes: Fragment registration (fragment register) is required before any computation
By default, only bonded contacts contribute to fragment connectivity (use ignorebond for all contacts)
Fragment ID 0 indicates isolated body (no contacts)
fragment activate enables automatic periodic computation; fragment compute is one-time
After computation, query fragment IDs via ball.fragment() or clump.fragment() in Python

commands.name: activate
commands.short_description: Activate fragment auto-computation

commands.name: clear
commands.short_description: Clear all fragment information

commands.name: compute
commands.short_description: Compute fragments based on current contact connectivity

commands.name: deactivate
commands.short_description: Deactivate fragment auto-computation

commands.name: list
commands.short_description: List fragment information

commands.name: register
commands.short_description: Register contact types for fragment analysis

measure.description: Measurement region creation and property analysis commands. Measurement regions calculate porosity, stress, strain, coordination number, and particle size distributions within spherical (3D) or circular (2D) regions.
typical_workflow: 1. Create measurement region: measure create radius 5.0
notes: Measurement regions are disks (2D) or spheres (3D)
Measurements calculated when 'model clean' is called or when FISH intrinsic queries measurement
Can measure: porosity, coordination number, stress, strain, size distribution
Use 'bins' keyword in create to enable particle size distribution calculation
Tolerance parameter controls accuracy vs. speed trade-off for porosity calculation

commands.name: create
commands.short_description: Create a measurement region

commands.name: delete
commands.short_description: Delete one or more measurement objects

commands.name: dump
commands.short_description: Dump the cumulative size distribution data from a measurement region

commands.name: history
commands.short_description: Add a measurement history

commands.name: list
commands.short_description: List information related to measurement regions

commands.name: modify
commands.short_description: Modify measurement region attributes

model.description: System-level commands for controlling simulation execution, configuration, and state management
notes: 'model solve' is preferred for reaching equilibrium (not available in Python SDK)
'model cycle' is equivalent to itasca.cycle() in Python
Model state can be saved/restored for checkpointing
Domain settings must be configured before generating objects
Use 'model solve' with ratio criteria for automatic convergence

commands.name: calm
commands.short_description: Calm the model
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('model calm') - Python SDK does not provide direct calm method

commands.name: clean
commands.short_description: Clean the model
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('model clean') or itasca.command('model clean all') - Python SDK does not provide direct clean method

commands.name: configure
commands.short_description: Configure an additional calculation mode
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('model configure cfd') - Python SDK does not provide direct configure method

commands.name: cycle
commands.short_description: Execute timesteps

commands.name: deterministic
commands.short_description: Set the deterministic mode
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('model deterministic on') or itasca.command('model deterministic off') - Python SDK does not provide direct deterministic control

commands.name: display
commands.short_description: Set information to display during cycling
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('model display ...') - Python SDK does not provide display control. For monitoring, use print statements or logging in Python loop with itasca.cycle() and itasca.fish_get()

commands.name: domain
commands.short_description: Specify the domain boundaries and conditions

commands.name: gravity
commands.short_description: Set the gravity as a vector or float

commands.name: history
commands.short_description: Create a history of a model quantity
commands.python_alternative:
itasca.command('model history mechanical ratio-average') - Python SDK does not provide direct history creation. For monitoring in Python, manually compute and store values in loops:

# Example: track metrics over cycles
history_data = []
for _ in range(100):
    itasca.cycle(100)
    # itasca.cycle() returns current cycle number
    history_data.append({'cycle': itasca.cycle(), 'time': itasca.mech_age(), ...})

commands.name: large-strain
commands.short_description: Sets the program to use the numerical formulation for large-strain deformation
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('model large-strain on') or itasca.command('model large-strain off') - Python SDK does not provide direct large-strain control

commands.name: mechanical
commands.short_description: Set parameters for a mechanical analysis

commands.name: new
commands.short_description: Clear model-state information
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('model new') or itasca.command('model new force') - Python SDK does not provide direct model.new() function

commands.name: orientation-tracking
commands.short_description: Specify the orientation tracking state
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('model orientation-tracking on') or itasca.command('model orientation-tracking off') - Python SDK does not provide direct orientation tracking control

commands.name: random
commands.short_description: Set the seed for the random-number generator
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('model random 12345') - Python SDK does not provide direct random seed control

commands.name: range
commands.short_description: Create/delete a named range
commands.python_alternative:
itasca.command('model range create "walls" group "West" or "East"')
itasca.command('ball attribute density 2500 range named-range "walls"')

# Python SDK does not provide direct range management. For dynamic range-based operations in Python, filter objects manually:

import itasca

# Example: filter balls by position
for ball in itasca.ball.list():
    pos = ball.pos()
    if 0 <= pos[0] <= 1 and 0 <= pos[1] <= 1:
        ball.set_density(2500)

commands.name: restore
commands.short_description: Restore program-state information
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('model restore "filename.f3sav"') - Python SDK does not provide direct restore function. Note: Use double quotes around filename in command string if path contains spaces

commands.name: results
commands.short_description: Perform file operations on results files
commands.python_alternative:
itasca.command('model results ...') - Python SDK does not provide direct results file control. For exporting states in Python, use:

# Setup automatic export
itasca.command('model results prefix "simulation"')
itasca.command('model results interval step 1000')

# Manual export
itasca.command('model results export "snapshot.p3result"')

# Import
itasca.command('model results import "snapshot.p3result"')

commands.name: save
commands.short_description: Save all model-state information
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('model save "filename.sav"') or itasca.command('model save "filename" compress') - Python SDK does not provide direct save function. Note: Use double quotes around filename in command string if path contains spaces

commands.name: solve
commands.short_description: Solve to a specified limit
commands.python_alternative:
itasca.command('model solve ratio 1e-5') - Python SDK does not provide direct solve() function. For custom solve loops in Python, manually compute equilibrium metrics:

import math
def vec_mag(v): return math.sqrt(v[0]**2 + v[1]**2 + v[2]**2)

while True:
    itasca.cycle(100)
    # Compute unbalanced force ratio manually:
    unbal_sum = sum(vec_mag(b.force_unbal()) for b in itasca.ball.list())
    contact_sum = sum(vec_mag(b.force_contact()) for b in itasca.ball.list())
    ratio = unbal_sum / contact_sum if contact_sum > 0 else 0
    if ratio < 1e-5:
        break

Note: Prefer 'model solve' command for standard equilibrium. Custom loops require manual force ratio calculations.

commands.name: thermal
commands.short_description: This command sets parameters for a thermal material analysis (only available if 'model configure ...
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('model thermal ...') - Python SDK does not provide direct thermal configuration. For thermal time: itasca.thermal_time() may be available depending on version

commands.name: update-interval
commands.short_description: Set the number of cycles taken between updating the existing plots in the user interface
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('model update-interval 100') - Python SDK does not provide direct update-interval control. Note: When running via Python SDK, visualization updates may behave differently

plot.description: Commands for creating, modifying, and exporting visualization plots. Controls plot items, camera views, and image export.
notes: Plot commands control visualization, not simulation
Use 'plot export bitmap' to save plot images
Plot item keywords are extensive; use 'plot export datafile' to inspect syntax
Camera view controlled via center, eye, magnification, projection keywords

commands.name: active
commands.short_description: Activate or deactivate a plot
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('plot <name> active <bool>') - no direct Python SDK method

commands.name: background
commands.short_description: Specifies the background color of the plot
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('plot <name> background <color>') - no direct Python SDK method

commands.name: clear
commands.short_description: Removes all plot items from the plot
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('plot <name> clear') - no direct Python SDK method

commands.name: copy
commands.short_description: Copy a plot to another plot
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('plot <name> copy <dest> <keyword>') - no direct Python SDK method

commands.name: create
commands.short_description: Create a new plot and make it the current (i
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('plot create <name>') - no direct Python SDK method

commands.name: current
commands.short_description: Make the specified plot the current (i
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('plot <name> current') - no direct Python SDK method

commands.name: delete
commands.short_description: Delete the specified plot
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('plot <name> delete') - no direct Python SDK method

commands.name: export
commands.short_description: Export the contents of a plot to a file
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('plot export bitmap filename <path>') - no direct Python SDK method

commands.name: item
commands.short_description: Create, destroy, or modify plot items associated with a plot
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('plot item create <type>') - no direct Python SDK method

commands.name: rename
commands.short_description: Rename a plot
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('plot <name> rename <newname>') - no direct Python SDK method

commands.name: title
commands.short_description: Set the font and settings used to render the title at the top of the plot
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('plot <name> title <text>') - no direct Python SDK method

commands.name: update
commands.short_description: Control automatic plot updates
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('plot <name> update <bool>') - no direct Python SDK method

commands.name: view
commands.short_description: Control the camera view of a plot
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('plot view <keyword> <value>') - no direct Python SDK method

wall.description: Commands for creating, modifying, and managing wall objects (faceted boundaries) in PFC
notes: Walls are composed of triangular facets (Facet objects)
Wall generation commands (box, cylinder) are not available in Python SDK
Use Python SDK for programmatic wall manipulation
Walls can be moved via velocity or displacement attributes

commands.name: active-sides
commands.short_description: Specify which side(s) of facets are active
commands.python_alternative: Facet.set_active(code) - codes: 0=both, 1=top (normal dir), -1=bottom, 2=neither. Requires iteration over facets

commands.name: addfacet
commands.short_description: Add a facet to a wall
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('wall addfacet ...') - Python SDK does not provide facet creation methods

commands.name: attribute
commands.short_description: Set the value of wall attributes
commands.python_alternative: Wall.set_*() methods (e.g., Wall.set_vel(), Wall.set_spin(), Wall.set_pos(), Wall.set_disp(), Wall.set_rotation_center()) - requires iteration over wall range

commands.name: create
commands.short_description: Create a wall from vertices
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('wall create ...') - Python SDK does not provide wall creation from vertices

commands.name: delete
commands.short_description: Delete walls and/or facets
commands.python_alternative: Wall.delete() or Facet.delete() methods - requires iteration: for w in itasca.wall.list(): w.delete() or for f in itasca.wall.facet.list(): f.delete()

commands.name: export
commands.short_description: Exports walls to geometry sets
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('wall export geometry ...') - Python SDK does not provide wall export functionality

commands.name: extra
commands.short_description: Set wall or facet extra variables
commands.python_alternative: Wall.set_extra(slot, value) or Facet.set_extra(slot, value) - requires iteration over wall/facet range

commands.name: generate
commands.short_description: Generate walls with specified shapes
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('wall generate ...') - Python SDK does not provide wall geometry generation

commands.name: group
commands.short_description: Specify wall or facet group names
commands.python_alternative: Wall.set_group(group_name, slot) or Facet.set_group(group_name, slot) for setting; Wall.group_remove(group_name, slot) or Facet.group_remove(group_name, slot) for removing - requires iteration over wall/facet range

commands.name: history
commands.short_description: Adds a history of a wall value
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('wall history ...') - Python SDK does not provide history recording. Use history commands for manipulation

commands.name: import
commands.short_description: Import a wall
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('wall import ...') - Python SDK does not provide wall import functionality

commands.name: initialize
commands.short_description: Synonym for the wall attribute command
commands.python_alternative: See wall attribute command for Python SDK methods

commands.name: list
commands.short_description: List wall information
commands.python_alternative: Use Wall object getter methods: wall.pos(), wall.vel(), wall.spin(), wall.disp(), wall.cutoff(), wall.extra(i), wall.group(slot), etc. Access walls via itasca.wall.list(). For contacts: wall.contacts(). For properties: iterate through wall.facets() and use facet.prop(name)

commands.name: property
commands.short_description: Assign facet surface properties used in contact models
commands.python_alternative: Wall.set_prop(name, value) to set property for all facets in a wall, or Facet.set_prop(name, value) for individual facets - requires iteration: for w in itasca.wall.list(): w.set_prop('kn', 1e7) or for f in itasca.wall.facet.list(): f.set_prop('kn', 1e7)

commands.name: resolution
commands.short_description: Modify the contact-resolution strategy for faceted walls
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('wall resolution ...') - Python SDK does not provide wall resolution settings. This is a global contact resolution strategy

commands.name: results
commands.short_description: Modify the usage of the wall results logic
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('wall results ...') - Python SDK does not provide wall results logic control. This is a global post-processing utility

commands.name: rotate
commands.short_description: Rotate walls
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('wall rotate ...') - Python SDK does not provide wall rotation functionality

commands.name: servo
commands.short_description: The wall servo provides the ability to control the translational velocity of select walls using a...
commands.python_alternative: Wall.servo_set_active(bool), Wall.servo_set_force(vec), Wall.servo_set_gainfactor(float), Wall.servo_set_gainupdate(int), Wall.servo_set_vmax(float) - requires iteration: for w in itasca.wall.list(): w.servo_set_active(True)

commands.name: tolerance
commands.short_description: Set contact detection tolerances
commands.python_alternative: itasca.command('wall tolerance ...') - Python SDK does not provide contact detection tolerance settings. This is a low-level algorithmic control

commands.name: velocity-conveyor
commands.short_description: Assign a rotational conveyor velocity to facets
commands.python_alternative: Facet.set_conveyor(vec) or Facet.set_conveyor_x/y/z(float) - requires manual calculation of tangential velocities and iteration: for w in itasca.wall.list(): for f in w.facets(): v_tangent = omega_cross_r; f.set_conveyor(v_tangent). For automatic calculation, use itasca.command('wall velocity-conveyor ...')

ball generate.reason: Python SDK doesn't support packing patterns for batch ball creation
ball generate.python_alternative: itasca.ball.create() - can create individual balls only
ball generate.python_workaround: Use itasca.ball.create() in a loop with manual positioning logic

wall generate.reason: Python SDK doesn't support geometric wall generation (box, cylinder, etc.)
wall generate.python_alternative: Manual wall creation using Python SDK requires vertex-by-vertex construction
wall generate.python_workaround: Calculate vertices manually and use itasca.wall module

clump template.reason: Python SDK does not provide clump template management
clump template.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump template ...') - must use command interface

clump generate.reason: Python SDK cannot generate clumps with templates and packing patterns
clump generate.python_alternative: itasca.command('clump generate ...') - must use command interface

model solve.reason: Python SDK doesn't have automatic equilibrium detection
model solve.python_workaround: Use itasca.cycle() with manual ratio checking in a loop

fragment register.reason: Fragment registration is a global initialization operation
fragment register.python_alternative: itasca.command('fragment register ...') - no direct SDK method

notes: Commands are preferred over Python SDK for batch operations and specialized geometries
Python SDK is preferred for fine-grained control and programmatic logic
Use 'itasca.command()' to execute any PFC command from Python
Commands return no value; use 'result' subcommands to query results
Most commands operate on ranges (groups, spatial regions, all objects)
